questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DIPLOMA LEVEL:MODERN APPLICATION DEVELOPMENT 2" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECT TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT ,PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)
question_texts: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DIPLOMA LEVEL:MODERN APPLICATION DEVELOPMENT 2" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECT TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT ,PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

options.option_text: A Vue component cannot access Vuex store state.

questions.question_text_1: Suppose you are writing an application to be used by lakhs of people, which will run a brute force algorithm and gives back the result to the user of the application when ready. Considering this context, arrange the below set of actions/operations to achieve a desirable and practical design.  I. Invoke the webhook II. Relieve the worker III. Dispatch a backend job
question_texts: Suppose you are writing an application to be used by lakhs of people, which will run a brute force algorithm and gives back the result to the user of the application when ready. Considering this context, arrange the below set of actions/operations to achieve a desirable and practical design.  I. Invoke the webhook II. Relieve the worker III. Dispatch a backend job

options.option_text: The polling will be a better design.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is true?
question_texts: Which of the following statements is true?

options.option_text: The CSRF protection is enforced by the flask framework, by default.
The data stored in local storage is synchronized across the devices for a givenuser.
A flask application returns CORS headers for cross domain javascript requests,by default.

questions.question_text_1: Suppose you want to store some data on the client, which has to be sent back to the server with every subsequent request. Which of the following is the most suited for this purpose?
question_texts: Suppose you want to store some data on the client, which has to be sent back to the server with every subsequent request. Which of the following is the most suited for this purpose?

options.option_text: Any of these can be used

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true regarding session cookies?
question_texts: Which of the following is true regarding session cookies?

options.option_text: They get deleted once the user closes the browser’s window.
They will be sent to the origin server with each request, by default.
They will not be sent to the origin server with each request, by default.

questions.question_text_1: Suppose you open “index.html” file in a browser, and type the text “EndTermExam” in the text box shown (after removing the previous text, if any), and hard refresh the page thrice, without clicking anywhere. What will be the value shown in the text box, and the “marks” placeholder, respectively?
question_texts: Suppose you open “index.html” file in a browser, and type the text “EndTermExam” in the text box shown (after removing the previous text, if any), and hard refresh the page thrice, without clicking anywhere. What will be the value shown in the text box, and the “marks” placeholder, respectively?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true in the context of point-to-point communication and message broker?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true in the context of point-to-point communication and message broker?

options.option_text: In point-to-point communication, the number of connections grow with theorder of O(nlogn).
If a central message broker is used, the number of connections grow with theorder of O(logn).
If a central message broker is used, the number of connections grow with theorder of O(n).
A message broker makes the network more scalable, if compared with point-to-point communication.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding caching?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding caching?

options.option_text: A shared cache is generally suitable for storing the personalized responses.
A private cache is usually tied to a specific client.
The caching helps in improving the performance of a web application.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding javascript language?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding javascript language?

options.option_text: JavaScript is a high level programming language.
JavaScript moves the declaration of all the arrow functions to the top of theirscope.
The language does not allow the global declaration of user defined functions.
A function can be invoked inside another function in the language.
The classes, namely “classA” and “classB” will always be applied to the divelement.
The class, namely “classB” will always be applied to the div element.
The class, namely “classA” will only be applied to the div element, if the variable“isClassA” evaluates to true.
The class, namely “classB” will only be applied to the div element, if no variablewith name “isClassA” exists.

questions.question_text_1: If an application is entirely built on the client end using javascript (without a database). Which of the following statements is/are false?
question_texts: If an application is entirely built on the client end using javascript (without a database). Which of the following statements is/are false?

options.option_text: All the progress will always be lost on the force reload of the page.
All the progress may not necessarily be lost on the force reload of the page.
The application will not allow force reload of the page.
The progress made in a machine can be accessed on another machine.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false in the context of scaling a web application?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false in the context of scaling a web application?

options.option_text: Scaling out is always a preferred choice when the network traffic is growing.
The horizontal scaling will typically clone the application as many times asrequired, and add a load balancer to maintain uniform traffic across the servers.
The horizontal partitioning splits a given table into multiple tables, with eachtable having the same structure.
The diagonal scaling refers to cloning the application first, and then scaling upthe different servers to meet the requirements.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: A flask application runs in a threaded mode by default.
A fetch API call always returns a promise.
The promise returned by fetch API resolves to an HTTP response status 500,with the “ok” property of the response set to true.
A headless CMS aims to manage both the content and frontend via APIs.
Slot ID: 1, Slot Status: Not Booked

questions.question_text_1: Suppose the application is running on ‘http://localhost:8080'. What will be rendered by the browser inside the div element with ID ‘slot-detail’, when user clicks on the button with the text ‘Book’ 3 times (except the button)?”
question_texts: Suppose the application is running on ‘http://localhost:8080'. What will be rendered by the browser inside the div element with ID ‘slot-detail’, when user clicks on the button with the text ‘Book’ 3 times (except the button)?”

options.option_text: Slot ID: 1, Slot Status: Not Booked

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **"Modern Application Development 2"** exam, along with a **Mermaid knowledge graph** to visualize relationships. --- --- ### **Core Topics & Concepts Summary** #### **1. Vue.js & Vuex** - **Vue Component Lifecycle**: `created`, `mounted`, `updated`, `destroyed`. - **Vuex State Management**: - `state`: Centralized data store. - `getters`: Computed properties for state. - `mutations`: Synchronous state updates. - `actions`: Asynchronous operations (commit mutations). - `mapState`: Helper to map store state to component computed properties. ```javascript computed: { ...mapState(['stateA', 'stateB']) // Maps stateA and stateB to computed properties. } ``` - **Vue Directives**: - `v-for`, `v-if`, `v-bind`, `v-on`, `v-model` (two-way binding). - Class binding: `:class="{ active: isActive }"`. - **Vue Router**: - Dynamic routing with `router-view` and nested routes. - Route parameters (`$route.params`) and query strings (`$route.query`). - Example: ```javascript const router = new VueRouter({ routes: [ { path: '/user/:id', component: User }, { path: '/search', component: Search, props: (route) => ({ query: route.query.q }) } ] }); ``` #### **2. JavaScript (ES6+)** - **Asynchronous JavaScript**: - **Promises**: `.then()`, `.catch()`, `.finally()`. ```javascript new Promise((resolve, reject) => { if (condition) resolve("Success"); else reject("Error"); }).then(data => console.log(data)).catch(err => console.error(err)); ``` - **Async/Await**: Syntactic sugar for promises. ```javascript async function fetchData() { const data = await apiCall(); console.log(data); } ``` - **Event Loop**: Microtasks (Promises) vs. Macrotasks (`setTimeout`, `setInterval`). - **Closures & `this` Binding**: - Arrow functions inherit `this` from the parent scope. - `call()`, `apply()`, `bind()` for explicit `this` binding. - **Error Handling**: - `try/catch` for synchronous code. - `.catch()` for promises. - **Hoisting**: `var` vs. `let/const`. #### **3. Web Security** - **Same-Origin Policy (SOP)**: - Restricts cross-origin requests unless CORS headers are present. - Origins must match: `protocol://domain:port`. - **Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)**: - Server must include `Access-Control-Allow-Origin` header. - **Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)**: - Attack tricks users into submitting unauthorized requests. - Mitigation: CSRF tokens, `SameSite` cookies. - **Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)**: - Injection of malicious scripts. - Mitigation: Sanitize inputs, use `Content Security Policy (CSP)`. - **Cookies**: - `Session` vs. `Persistent` cookies. - Attributes: `Secure`, `HttpOnly`, `SameSite`. - Session cookies are deleted when the browser closes (but **not by default**; they are deleted when the session ends). - **Key Point**: Cookies are sent to the server with **every request** by default. #### **4. Client-Side Storage** | Mechanism | Persistence | Scope | Sent to Server | Use Case | |-----------------|-------------------|----------------|----------------|-----------------------------------| | **Cookies** | Configurable | Domain-wide | Yes | Session management, tracking. | | **Local Storage** | Persistent | Origin | No | Offline data, user preferences. | | **Session Storage** | Session-only | Tab-specific | No | Temporary data (e.g., form drafts). | - **Local Storage vs. Session Storage**: - Local Storage: Persists across sessions. - Session Storage: Cleared when the tab closes. #### **5. Backend & Scalability** - **Flask Defaults**: - **Not threaded by default** (unless using a production server like Gunicorn). - **No built-in CSRF protection** (requires `flask_wtf.csrf`). - **No CORS headers by default** (requires `flask_cors`). - **Scaling Strategies**: - **Horizontal Scaling (Scale Out)**: Add more servers + load balancer. - **Vertical Scaling (Scale Up)**: Increase server resources (CPU/RAM). - **Diagonal Scaling**: Combine horizontal and vertical scaling. - **Database Partitioning**: - **Horizontal Partitioning (Sharding)**: Split rows across tables. - **Vertical Partitioning**: Split columns into separate tables. - **Message Brokers (e.g., RabbitMQ, Kafka)**: - Reduce point-to-point connections from `O(n²)` to `O(n)`. - Improve scalability and decoupling. #### **6. Caching** | Cache Type | Scope | Use Case | |-----------------|---------------------|-----------------------------------| | **Private Cache** | Client-specific | Personalized data (e.g., user sessions). | | **Shared Cache** | Shared across users | Static assets (e.g., images, CSS). | - **Benefits**: Reduce latency, offload server load. #### **7. REST & APIs** - **Fetch API**: - Always returns a `Promise`. - Response `ok` property: - `true` for status codes `200-299`. - `false` for `404`, `500`, etc. - **Webhooks vs. Polling**: - **Webhooks**: Server pushes data to client (event-driven). - **Polling**: Client repeatedly checks for updates (inefficient). #### **8. Modern JavaScript Frameworks** - **Vue.js**: - Reactive data binding (`{{ data }}`). - Component-based architecture. - **Reactivity in Vue**: - `data()` properties are reactive. - Computed properties cache results. #### **9. Design Patterns** - **Observer Pattern**: Used in Vue’s reactivity system. - **Factory Pattern**: Promise factories for async operations. - **Singleton Pattern**: Vuex store (single source of truth). --- --- ### **Key Equations & Code Snippets** #### **1. Vuex `mapState`** ```javascript computed: { ...mapState(['stateA', 'stateB']) // Maps stateA and stateB to computed properties. } ``` #### **2. Promise Chaining** ```javascript promiseFactory(data) .then(result => { console.log(result); return anotherPromise(); }) .catch(error => console.error(error)); ``` #### **3. Async/Await** ```javascript async function fetchData() { try { const data = await apiCall(); console.log(data); } catch (error) { console.error(error); } } ``` #### **4. Vue Class Binding** ```html
``` #### **5. Fetch API** ```javascript fetch('https://api.example.com/data') .then(response => { if (!response.ok) throw new Error('Network error'); return response.json(); }) .then(data => console.log(data)) .catch(error => console.error(error)); ``` #### **6. Vue Router Dynamic Routes** ```javascript const router = new VueRouter({ routes: [ { path: '/user/:id', component: User, props: true } ] }); ``` #### **7. Event Loop Example** ```javascript console.log('Start'); setTimeout(() => console.log('Timeout'), 0); Promise.resolve().then(() => console.log('Promise')); console.log('End'); // Output: Start → End → Promise → Timeout ``` #### **8. CSRF Protection (Flask)** ```python from flask_wtf.csrf import CSRFProtect app = Flask(__name__) csrf = CSRFProtect(app) ``` #### **9. CORS in Flask** ```python from flask_cors import CORS app = Flask(__name__) CORS(app) # Enable CORS for all routes ``` #### **10. Local Storage** ```javascript localStorage.setItem('key', 'value'); const data = localStorage.getItem('key'); ``` --- --- ### **Mermaid Knowledge Graph** ```mermaid %% Core Topics in Modern Application Development 2 graph TD %% Vue.js A[Vue.js] --> B[Components] A --> C[Directives: v-for, v-if, v-bind] A --> D[Vuex] D --> D1[State] D --> D2[Getters] D --> D3[Mutations] D --> D4[Actions] D --> D5[mapState] A --> E[Vue Router] E --> E1[Dynamic Routes] E --> E2[Nested Routes] %% JavaScript F[JavaScript ES6+] --> G[Promises] G --> G1[.then/.catch] G --> G2[Async/Await] F --> H[Event Loop] H --> H1[Microtasks] H --> H2[Macrotasks] F --> I[Closures & this] I --> I1[Arrow Functions] I --> I2[call/apply/bind] %% Web Security J[Web Security] --> K[Same-Origin Policy] K --> K1[CORS] J --> L[CSRF] L --> L1[CSRF Tokens] J --> M[XSS] M --> M1[Input Sanitization] J --> N[Cookies] N --> N1[Secure/HttpOnly] N --> N2[SameSite] %% Client-Side Storage O[Client-Side Storage] --> P[Cookies] O --> Q[Local Storage] O --> R[Session Storage] %% Backend & Scalability S[Backend] --> T[Flask] T --> T1[Threading] T --> T2[CSRF Protection] T --> T3[CORS] S --> U[Scaling] U --> U1[Horizontal] U --> U2[Vertical] U --> U3[Diagonal] U --> U4[Message Brokers] %% Caching V[Caching] --> W[Private Cache] V --> X[Shared Cache] %% REST APIs Y[REST APIs] --> Z[Fetch API] Z --> Z1[Promises] Z --> Z2[Response Handling] %% Design Patterns AA[Design Patterns] --> AB[Observer] AA --> AC[Factory] AA --> AD[Singleton] %% Connections A --> F D --> O E --> J T --> Z U --> V ``` ```mermaid %% Asynchronous JavaScript Flow graph LR A[Synchronous Code] --> B[Macrotask Queue: setTimeout] A --> C[Microtask Queue: Promises] B --> D[Event Loop] C --> D D --> E[Call Stack] E --> F[Render] ``` ```mermaid %% Vuex Data Flow graph TD A[Component] -->|Dispatch| B[Action] B -->|Commit| C[Mutation] C -->|Update| D[State] D -->|Render| A D -->|Getters| A ``` ```mermaid %% Scaling Strategies graph TD A[Monolithic App] -->|Scale Up| B[Vertical Scaling] A -->|Scale Out| C[Horizontal Scaling] C --> D[Load Balancer] D --> E[Clone 1] D --> F[Clone 2] D --> G[Clone N] C --> H[Message Broker] H --> E H --> F H --> G ```
